claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 139:
When a period is provided for in hours, the period commences immediately at the specified time.



        Conclusion:
        If an agreement is made at 10:00 a.m. on June 3 of a given year that the obligation will be fulfilled within five hours,the period commences at 10:00 a.m. of the same day, which does not fall on Sunday, holiday as provided in the Act on National Holidays, or any other holiday..'''
argument: The argument is valid because according to Article 139, when a period is provided for in hours, it commences immediately at the specified time. Therefore, if an agreement is made at 10:00 a.m. on June 3 that the obligation will be fulfilled within five hours, the period indeed commences at 10:00 a.m. on the same day, as the statute clearly states that the period starts immediately. The conclusion logically follows from the premise, assuming the day is not a Sunday, holiday, or any other day specified in the Act on National Holidays, as the premise does not mention any exceptions for such days.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 102:
An act that a person with qualified legal capacity performs as an agent of another person may not be rescinded on the grounds of qualified legal capacity; provided, however, that this does not apply to an act performed by a person with qualified legal capacity as a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity.
(Authority of an Agent with No Specifically Defined Authority)



        Conclusion:
        A contract may not be rescinded by the principal after it is performed by an agent with a counterparty even if it turns out that the agent was a person with limited capacity..'''
argument: The conclusion logically follows from the premises as stated in Article 102. The premise clearly states that an act performed by an agent with qualified legal capacity cannot be rescinded on the grounds of that capacity, unless the agent is acting as a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity. Since the conclusion specifies that the agent performed the contract and the principal seeks to rescind it based on the agent's limited capacity, this directly aligns with the premise, supporting the conclusion that the contract may not be rescinded.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 9:
A juridical act performed by an adult ward is voidable; provided, however, that this does not apply to the purchase of daily necessities or to any other act involved in day-to-day life.
(Rescission of Decisions for Commencement of Guardianship)



        Conclusion:
        The purchase of daily household items may not be rescinded, even if an adult ward performed the act..'''
argument: The conclusion logically follows from the premises as stated in Article 9, which explicitly states that a juridical act performed by an adult ward is voidable, except for the purchase of daily necessities or any other act involved in day-to-day life. Since the purchase of daily household items falls under the category of daily necessities or day-to-day life, it cannot be rescinded, thus supporting the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 243:
If two or more movable properties with different owners can no longer be separated without damage due to accession, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property. The same applies if excessive expense is required to separate the movables.



        Conclusion:
        If two or more movables with different owners are so joined to each other that they can no longer be separated without damaging the same, ownership of the composite Thing shall vest in the owner of the principal movables..'''
argument: The conclusion logically follows from the premises as stated in Article 243. The premise clearly states that if two or more movable properties with different owners can no longer be separated without damage due to accession, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property. This directly supports the conclusion that if two or more movables with different owners are so joined that they cannot be separated without damage, ownership of the composite thing shall vest in the owner of the principal movables.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 192:
A person that commences the possession of movables peacefully and openly by a transactional act acquires the rights that are exercised with respect to the movables immediately if the person possesses it in good faith and without negligence.
(Recovery of Stolen or Lost Property)



        Conclusion:
        A took the jewelry that B had forgotten, believing without negligence that it belonged to A. In this case, A may not obtain the ownership of the jewelry by good faith acquisition..'''
argument: The conclusion correctly applies the principle of good faith acquisition as stated in Article 192. Since A took the jewelry believing it belonged to them and without negligence, the situation does not meet the full criteria for good faith acquisition as A did not acquire the jewelry through a transactional act. Therefore, A may not obtain ownership of the jewelry.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 356:
The pledgee of immovables may use and profit from the immovables that are the subject matter of a pledge in line with the way the relevant immovables are used.
(Management Expenses Borne by Pledgees of Immovables)



        Conclusion:
        In pledges of immovables, pledgees and a pledgors may conclude a special provision that the pledgees may not use and receive the profits from the immovable property that is the subject matter of the pledge..'''
argument: The conclusion is a valid interpretation of Article 356, as it allows for the possibility of a special provision between the pledgee and the pledgor. Article 356 states that the pledgee may use and profit from the immovables, but it does not explicitly prohibit the parties from agreeing to a different arrangement. Therefore, the conclusion that a special provision can be made, stipulating that the pledgee may not use and receive profits from the immovable property, is consistent with the flexibility implied in the statute.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 423-6:
If the obligee files an action concerning the exercise of the subrogor's right, the obligee must give a notice of suit to the obligor without delay.
(Obligee's Right of Subrogation to Preserve the Right to Request Registration)



        Conclusion:
        If the obligee files an action concerning the exercise of the subrogor's right, the obligee must give a notice of suit to the obligor without delay..'''
argument: The argument is valid because the conclusion is a direct restatement of the premise provided in Article 423-6. The premise clearly states that if the obligee files an action concerning the exercise of the subrogor's right, the obligee must give a notice of suit to the obligor without delay. The conclusion is identical to this premise, thus the premises logically entail the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 3-2:
If the person making a juridical act did not have mental capacity when manifesting the relevant intention, the juridical act is void.
Section 3 Capacity to Act
(Age of Majority)



        Conclusion:
        If a party to a contract did not have mental capacity when manifesting the relevant intention, the nullity of the contract may be asserted even against a third party in good faith and acting without negligence..'''
argument: The conclusion logically follows from the premises because if a person lacks mental capacity when manifesting the relevant intention, as stated in Article 3-2, the juridical act, which includes a contract, is void. Since a void contract is inherently invalid, it can be asserted as null even against a third party in good faith and acting without negligence, as the lack of mental capacity fundamentally undermines the validity of the contract from the outset.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 378:
If a third party that purchases the ownership or superficies of a mortgaged immovables pays the price of the same to a mortgagee at the request of the same mortgagee, that mortgage is terminated for the benefit of that third party.
(Claims for Extinguishment of Mortgages)



        Conclusion:
        A created a mortgage on Land X, owned by A, for the benefit of B and thereafter sold Land X to C. In this case, if C pays the price of the same to B at the request of B, the mortgage shall be terminated..'''
argument: The argument is valid because it directly follows the stipulation provided in Article 378. The article states that if a third party (in this case, C) pays the price of the mortgaged immovables (Land X) to the mortgagee (B) at the request of the mortgagee, the mortgage is terminated for the benefit of that third party. Since the conditions specified in the article are met (C pays B at B's request), the conclusion that the mortgage shall be terminated is logically entailed by the premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 543:
If non-performance of an obligation is due to grounds attributable to the obligee, the obligee may not cancel the contract under the preceding two Articles.
(Indivisible Nature of Right to Cancel)



        Conclusion:
        In the contract for sale between A and B, the quantity of the subject matter delivered by the seller A to the buyer B is insufficient and does not conform to the terms of the contract. If the insufficiency in the quantity is due to grounds attributable to B, B may not cancel the contract for sale between A and B..'''
argument: The argument is valid because it directly applies the principle stated in Article 543. According to the statute, if the non-performance of an obligation is due to grounds attributable to the obligee (in this case, B), the obligee (B) may not cancel the contract. Since the insufficiency in the quantity of the subject matter delivered by A is due to grounds attributable to B, B is precluded from canceling the contract, as per the statute.
